pullRequest.body:
Define basic things about filtered ring.
Including `IsFiltration` for abelian group, `IsRingFiltration` for semiring, and `IsModuleFiltration` for module, with the special case indexed with integer.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

-->

### PR summary [8fd92dc8cf](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20900/commits/8fd92dc8cfcbb542e24ea2c34ab3130cd784d488)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.FilteredAlgebra.Basic` (new file)|590|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsFiltration`
`+ IsFiltration.F_lt_le_F`
`+ IsFiltration.mk_int`
`+ IsModuleFiltration`
`+ IsModuleFiltration.mk_int`
`+ IsRingFiltration`
`+ IsRingFiltration.mk_int`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
@eric-wieser Do you have anything more to say about this one?

:v: Thmoas-Guan can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks!

bors d+

Thanks!

bors d+
Can you move this to the docstring of `IsFiltration` so that it appears in the web docs?

```suggestion
  mono : Monotone F
```
In your current PR, `F_lt` is not ever "used"; could you explain on where you expect it to appear? Do you have some draft downstream code that relies on it?

In #20913 for constructing the assoctiated graded ring and #20940 for constructing the associated graded module.
I think quotient by `F_lt` is what we usually do when indexed by integer or real number.

I also have some doubts about the inclusion of `F_lt` (though perhaps it is the right move).

If I understand correctly, to define the associated graded structures, you need a collection of subobjects satisfying the conditions with which you have endowed `F_lt` here. Furthermore it seems that in the presence of `[CompleteLattice ]` such a collection is ` i < j, F i`. But since `` is playing the role of a subset / subgroup / subring it seems to me that we should always have the complete lattice assumption. So I am left wondering why we want `F_lt`.

I can study the downstream PRs in more detail to understand the motivation but it is likely to speed you your review time substantially if it is possible to emphasise the key issue :-)

This thing started from the simple trouble that `[CompleteLattice ]` is not a prop and doesn't have the corresponding version, we can't add it onto the preorder given by `SetLike`. As @chrisflav came out with this idea, we found that this also have the benefit of having the thing under the quotient able to be choose by youself, which can be in the most comfortable form in special cases, such as when indexed with integer or natural number it can be written out explicitly.

One reason for introducing the `F_lt` field, instead of setting it to the supremum, is to get good definitional properties for the associated graded ring in the case where the index type is totally ordered, e.g. the integers. Here `F_lt` can be chosen to be `F (n-1)`. This is one of the most common applications of this API.
The second reason is the conflict with `SetLike` and `CompleteLattice` that Nailin mentioned. We don't want to restrict to `AddSubgroup`s because the same API should also work for submodules or ideals without additional casts.
@ocfnash  are you satisfied with this reason? As there are quite a lot of codes that have already based on it, I want to work on downstream with a stable definition, thanks.

I'm sorry not have have been able to return to this sooner (I currently have very limited time for review, and there are many PRs).

I am still curious about other approaches to the issues you raise and with infinite time I might explore these but this design is a good one, and we can accept it. 

Thank you for your patience.

```suggestion
  mul x y := x.1 * y.1, by simpa using IsRingFiltration.mul_mem x.2 y.2
  left_distrib a b c := SetCoe.ext (mul_add a.1 b.1 c.1)
  right_distrib a b c := SetCoe.ext (add_mul a.1 b.1 c.1)
```
etc

```suggestion
lemma IsFiltration_int (F :   ) (mono : Monotone F) :
```

```suggestion
lemma IsFiltration.mk_int (F :   ) (mono : Monotone F) :
```
since the autogenerated constructor above is called `IsFiltration.mk`.

Same for the similar lemma below.

style nit (througout) - spaces and trailing `.`:
```suggestion
/-- A special case of `IsFiltration` when index is integer. -/
```

style nit (throughout):
```suggestion
    IsRingFiltration F (fun n  F (n - 1)) where
  __ := IsFiltration_int F mono
  one_mem := one_mem
  mul_mem := mul_mem
```
Sorry that I have another qusetion though, how does this notation work?
This won't be visible in any documentation; can you move it somewhere where it can be seen, either on a `class` or the module docs?
I moved it into doc of `IsModuleFiltration`

```suggestion
class IsRingFiltration (F :   ) (F_lt : outParam <|   )
    extends IsFiltration F F_lt, SetLike.GradedMonoid F : Prop where
```
and add `import Mathlib.Algebra.GradedMonoid` at the top.
Another question, is there a corresponding thing for Module? Thanks.
Perhaps `SetLike.GradedSMul`?
Thanks, maybe I can refactor it all.

With the change above, you can delete this instance entirely, as it's just [`SetLike.GradeZero.instSemiring`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/DirectSum/Internal.html#SetLike.GradeZero.instSemiring).
You can replace these `mem`s with a single `[SetLike.GradedMonoid F]` argument, and also drop the two `mem` lines below

A style nit (here and below):
```suggestion
section GeneralFiltration
variable {  A : Type*}
variable [Preorder ] [SetLike  A]
```

Putting all the types first makes it a little easier to use lemmas with `@`. The blank lines between `variable` are largely a mathport artifact, and are not required by the style guide.

```suggestion
* `IsRingFiltration` : For `` satisfying `SetLike  R` where `R` is a semiring,
  an increasing series `F` in `` is ring filtration if `IsFiltration F F_lt` and
  the pointwise multiplication of `F i` and `F j` is in `F (i + j)`
```
and below

```suggestion
In this file, we define the fitration on abelian groups,
and extend it to get the filtration on rings.
```

```suggestion
# The filtration on abelian groups and rings
```
Please indent all these bullets in the same way.

```suggestion
  an increasing series `F` in `` is a ring filtration if `IsFiltration F F_lt` and
```

```suggestion
a module filtration if `IsFiltration F F_lt` and the pointwise scalar multiplication of
```
This mistake is present in the docstrings below too.

```suggestion
Copyright (c) 2025 Nailin Guan. All rights reserved.
```
I assume this work started last year
I think I should change though, this was written when our repo was created, however the refactor was done this year, I forgot to change the date.

```suggestion
In this file, we define the concept of filtration for abelian groups, rings, and modules.
```

```suggestion
/-- A convenience constructor for `IsFiltration` when the index is the integers. -/
```

Although this is a good doc string, it is quite technical. I tend to think that the doc string is a great place to use more informal language, optimised to help a reader not necessarily familiar with all aspects of the library. After all: the precise details do exist in the Lean.

You don't need to change these doc strings unless you want, but I might be tempted to use words like "subsets" instead of `SetLike  A` etc.
Good suggestion, I'll have some change, can you have a look?

```suggestion
class IsModuleFiltration (F :   ) (F_lt : outParam <|   ) [IsRingFiltration F F_lt]
```

```suggestion
    letI := IsRingFiltration.mk_int F mono
    IsModuleFiltration
```
Thanks, I added the name because got trouble with this.

```suggestion
In the intended applications, `` is a complete lattice, and `F_lt` is uniquely-determined as
`F_lt j =  i < j, F i`. Thus `F_lt` is an implementation detail which allows us defer depending
on a complete lattice structure on ``. It also provides the ancillary benefit of giving us better
definition control. This is convenient e.g., when the index is ``. -/
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra): define filtered ring
